application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: the latter one provides a finer control of the feed-mounted lower platform. In the experiment, the Gough-Stewart platform demonstrates a good performance in controlling the position and orientation of the lower platform, though its upper platform is supported by flexible cables. Accuracy and sampling rate of the optical sensors play an important role in achieving high-precision control. The test results assure the controllability and the effectiveness of the proposed feed-support configuration for the large radio telescope in high-accuracy positioning of the receiver. Further studies for higher wind excitation conditions and dynamically optimized Gough-Stewart platform are under way.

div.head: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
div.p: Thanks are extended to W. Shaobo, Z. Qian, and Q. Lin who have been participants in the experiments, and also to Prof P. D. Cha for polishing the English.

div.head: Integration of Saturated PI Synchronous Control and PD Feedback for Control of Parallel Manipulators
div.p: Yuxin Su, Dong Sun, Lu Ren, and James K. Mills

Abstract-High-precision motion of parallel manipulators depends not only on the position accuracy of each actuator, but also on the position synchronization of all actuators. This paper presents a simple synchronized control algorithm for the setpoint position control of parallel manipulators, by incorporating cross-coupling technology into a common proportional-derivative (PD) control architecture. An integrated controller is developed, consisting of a PD control and a saturated proportional-integral (S-PI) control with feedback of the differential position errors amongst actuators (defined as the synchronization errors). The controller can stabilize the motion of each actuator, and meanwhile synchronize all actuators' motions so that both position and synchronization errors converge to zero. The control algorithm does not use the modeling parameters in the controller formulation, and thus permits easy implementation in practice. It is proved that the proposed method can guarantee global asymptotical stability of the system. Experiments conducted on a planar three-degree-of-freedom parallel manipulator demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.
Index Terms-Cross-coupling control, parallel manipulators, proportional-derivative (PD) control, saturated proportional-integral (S-PI) control, synchronization.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: Parallel manipulators have been widely used due to their high stiffness, high accuracy, and high load-carrying capacity over their counterpart, serial manipulators [1]. Due to the fact that the dynamic equations of motion of parallel manipulators involve more system parameters and are more complex than serial manipulators, development of effective controllers for parallel manipulators to follow a trajectory precisely and quickly is somewhat more complex. There are two basic strategies used for control of parallel manipulators [2], nonmodel-based controls such as proportional-integral-derivative (PID) control [2], [3], fuzzy logic control [4], and neural network control [5]; and model-based controls such as impedance control [6] and adaptive control [7], [8], etc.

In most existing controllers for parallel manipulators, the control loop for one actuator does not receive information from other actuators. Hence, disturbances in the control loop of one actuator result in an error that is corrected by this loop only, while other actuator control loops do not respond, and hence exhibit unwanted coupling errors. This lack of synchronization amongst control loops degrades the overall motion performance, because the trajectory of the mobile platform depends on all actuator motions. Furthermore, since the actuators of the parallel manipulator are arranged in parallel, the lack of synchronization amongst actuators may result in large unwanted interaction forces amongst each other, and hence, in excessive wear of the actuator and mechanical components. Cross-coupling control [9] provides an opportunity to solve the synchronization problem of parallel manipulators. There have been remarkable efforts using cross-coupling control technology to improve synchronization performance of multiaxis motions [10]- [14]. Applications of the cross-coupling approach to robotics include mobile robot control [15], [16] and manipulator coordination [17]- [19]. A Cartesian cross-coupling control technology was reported to reduce the Cartesian space contour error of a 3-PRPS platform [20]. It is noted that all approaches mentioned above relied on system modeling.

In this paper, an integrated control that consists of a common proportional-derivative (PD) feedback and a saturated proportional-integral (S-PI) control is proposed for controlling parallel manipulators in a synchronous manner. This work is motivated by the approach of [21], that a saturated PID control gives rise to global asymptotic stability for a local PID feedback. In this paper, the concept of saturated control is used for synchronization purposes. A new class of saturated function is derived from a quasi-natural potential function. The position synchronization error, which is defined as the differential position error with coupling parameters derived from the kinematic relationship amongst the platform actuators, is used to replace the position error in the S-PI feedback. The control algorithm does not contain system modeling parameters explicitly, and thus, it is readily implemented. It is proved that such an integrated controller guarantees global asymptotical stability of the closed-loop system. Experiments conducted on a planar three-degree-of-freedom (DOF) parallel manipulator demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

The proposed synchronous controller is applicable to many other multiaxis systems, but it has special significance for parallel manipulators. It has long been assumed that the closed kinematic chain of a parallel manipulator creates a tight nonlinear coupling and requires careful modeling and a model-based approach to achieve the desired performance. The result of this paper supports the concept that the performance can be enhanced by including a simple synchronized cross-coupling controller into a PD-control architecture.

div.head: II. MODELING AND SYNCHRONIZATION CONTROL STRATEGY
div.p: Consider a planar parallel manipulator [22], which consists of a triangular moving platform, a triangular base, and three legs, as shown in Fig. 1. Each leg consists of an actuated prismatic joint, two consecutive nonactuated revolute joints, and an intermediate link. Both ends of the intermediate link are composed of nonactuated revolute joints.

Since the prismatic joints move along the linear guides fixed to the base, and the revolute joints rotate in the horizontal plane, the moving platform exhibits translational and rotational motions in the horizontal plane. The inertial frame O-XY is fixed on the base with its origin at the geometric center of the base. The motion of the moving platform is represented by coordinates of the center of the moving platform with respect to the inertial frame, denoted by the position p and the orientation .

Define q = [q 1 111q n ] 2 < n21 as the generalized coordinates (where n = 3 in Fig. 1), in which qi denotes translation of the ith prismatic joint. Using time derivatives of the generalized coordinates and the pose of the moving platform, we have _p(t) = (Jp(t)) 01 _q(t) (1) where J p 2 < n2n is the Jacobian matrix representing the velocity relationship between the actuated joints and the moving platform.
Using the natural orthogonal-complement method, the dynamic model of such a parallel manipulator is [21], [23] H(q) q + B0 + 1 2 _ H(q) + S(q; _q) _q =

where H(q) is the symmetric and positive-definite inertia matrix, B0 denotes a diagonal viscous friction matrix, S(q; _q) is a nonlinear skewsymmetric matrix, and 2 < n denotes control inputs. Note that ( 2) is expressed in terms of its minimal or actuation coordinates. The planar parallel manipulator system to be considered admits a closed-form expression for kinematics (see details in [24]), and hence allows development of (2) in terms of actuator coordinates.

As for a parallel manipulator with n actuators in the setpoint control, the synchronization goal [18] can be defined as q 1 (t) q d 1 = q 2 (t) q d 2 = 111 = q n (t) q d n ; (i = 1; ...;n) (3) where q d i denotes the desired coordinate of each actuator. The rationale behind this goal is the observation that, when all ratios of (3) are equal, the manipulator moves in a synchronous manner. Hence, synchronization is achieved, and the desired pose of the movable platform is attained. Rewrite (3) as a set of subgoals, namely, (qi(t))=(q d i ) = (q i+1 (t))=(q d i+1 ) = (q i01 (t))=(q d i01 ), where q i+1 and q i01 are understood to be q 1 and q n when i = n and 1, respectively. Then, a series of synchronization functions corresponding to these subgoals are derived as fi(qi; qi+1; qi01) = 2 q i (t)

(20) Figs. 34illustrate top views of the actual and desired trajectories of the platform with the two control methods. It can be seen that the actual path better matches the desired path in Fig. 3 than in Fig. 4, which indicates that the proposed saturated synchronization control exhibits improved motion performance, compared with the standard PID control.

To clearly show such performance improvement with the proposed synchronous control, Figs. 5-6 illustrate a comparison between the two methods in the position and orientation errors of the platform, and position errors of the three prismatic joints. Obviously, the saturated synchronization control exhibits much smaller errors. Such performance improvement results from smaller synchronization errors of the three prismatic joints, as shown in Fig. 7. Table I gives a summary of the maximum errors with these two methods. It can be seen from these experimental results that the proposed saturated synchronization control improves motion performance in controlling the parallel manipulator system.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: A simple synchronous control strategy is proposed for precision control of parallel manipulators, by incorporating cross-coupling technology into a common PD control architecture. The proposed controller is an integration of the S-PI control with feedback of the defined synchronization errors, and a common PD feedback. The algorithm does not require modeling parameters in the controller formulation, and therefore, is easy to implement in practice. It is proven that this controller guarantees global asymptotic stability of the closed-loop system. Experiments conducted on a planar 3-DOF parallel manipulator demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

Since the inner product of the LHS of (29) with (E(q d )s(")) T must satisfy (20), there exists only one point E(q d )s(") = 0 that can satisfy (29). Since E(q d ) has full rank, s(") = 0. From the definition of s("), we have " = 0. We further have 1q = 0 from (8).

Hence, it has been shown that the invariant set itself is composed of the single state (q d ; _q = 0;" = 0), which is also the maximum invariant set of (15). LaSalle's invariance theorem now shows that for any initial state (q(0); _q(0)),thesolutionto(15)convergesgloballyand asymptotically to the equilibrium state (q d ; _q = 0;" = 0) as t ! 1.

Theorem 1 indicates that the combination of the S-PI control and a common PD control can asymptotically stabilize position error 1q ! 0 while synchronizing all actuators' motions so that " ! 0. Inclusion of the synchronization error feedback in the controller enhances convergence of the synchronization error " to zero.

div.head: IV. EXPERIMENTS
div.p: To verify the effectiveness of the proposed integrated controller, experiments were performed on a 3-DOF planar parallel manipulator, as shown in Fig. 2. The details of the kinematics can be found in [24]. The control system consists of a 400 MHz Pentium II PC, a MCX-DSP-ISA 120 Mflop/s DSP controller, and three Aerotech BA20 SineDrive amplifiers. The movable platform is actuated by an Aerotech BM200 DC brushless motor via a THK KR3306 ball-screw with the lead of 6 mm. A built-in rotary encoder on the DC motor feeds back the angular position. The sampling period is 1 ms.
The moving platform was required to move along straight lines to complete the following set-point control motions: P0(0; 0; 44:3) !
